string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

search.slidetext: select a term to learn more. abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

agitation stage 3 of the seven phases of behaviour escalation. the student loses focus, and they are more visibly upset. acceleration stage 4 of the seven phases of behaviour escalation. if the conflict continues to be unresolved, the behaviour of the student will escalate and may become more intense. a-b-c analysis a descriptive assessment undertaken over a period of time that considers the antecedent, behaviour and consequences. it involves the collection of data within the context of where the behaviour occurs, and can be used as a tool to determine the function of behaviours. a-b-c analysis acceleration agitation a abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
b abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

cues quick verbal and non-verbal reminders of expected behaviours. crisis management plan a plan needed for students who engage in behaviours that place themselves and/or others at risk. consequences the event/s that happens immediately after the behaviour occurs. competing pathways plan this plan can help simplify using results from an fba (functional behaviour assessment) or a-b-c (antecedent, behaviour and consequences) analysis to develop an individual behaviour support plan. community circles an approach to group discussion that draws upon the practices of indigenous cultures from around the world, including from aboriginal and torres strait islander peoples in australia. calm stage 1 of the seven phases of behaviour escalation. the student is calm, cooperative and engaged. c calm community circles competing pathways plan consequences crisis management plan cues abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

dysregulate unable to self-regulate or self-manage emotions and often have emotional responses that are out of sync with the situation. disruption disturbance or problems which interrupt an event, activity or process. discipline the practice of training people toobeyrules or a code of behaviour, using punishment to correctdisobedience. de-escalation stage 6 of the seven phases of behaviour escalation. the student will start to calm and a drop in the intensity of the expressed emotion will be visible. d de-escalation discipline disruption dysregulate abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

extrinsic motivation motivation that is not part of the essential nature of someone or something; coming or operating from outside. expectation a strong belief that something will happen or be the case. escalation an increase in the intensity orseriousnessof something; anintensification. e escalation expectation extrinsic motivation abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

funds of knowledge skills and knowledge students develop through their interactions with family, community members and peers, and embedded in cultural practices. functional behaviour assessment (fba) an intensive process that involves the systematic collection of data undertaken by a team within the school setting. fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (fasd) a diagnostic term used to describe impacts on the brain and body of individuals prenatally exposed to alcohol. f fetal alcohol spectrum disorder functional behaviour assessment funds of knowledge abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

gesture a movement of part of the body, especially a hand or the head, to express an idea or meaning. gamification the application of game design elements and principles to boost student motivation, engagement and learning outcomes. some common aspects include points, badges, leaderboards and the incorporation of narratives or role-play. g gamification gesture abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
h abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

intrinsic motivation motivation that is belonging naturally; essential. intersectionality how different aspects of a persons identity can expose them to overlapping forms of discrimination and marginalisation. e.g. a gifted student who lives in low-socioeconomic circumstances. intellectual disability intellectual disability is a lifelong condition that affects a persons intellectual skills and behaviour in different situations. implicit-association test (iat) atest designed by harvard university to predict unconscious biases individuals may have toward different social groups. i implicit-association test intellectual disability intersectionality intrinsic motivation abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
j abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
k abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
l abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
m abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

directions or instructions given that are not verbally explained. non-verbal strategies neurodivergent refers to individuals whose brain functions, processes information, learns and/or behaves differently from what is considered "typical" or "normal" in society. it encompasses a wide range of neurological conditions and differences. neurodivergent n neurodivergent non-verbal strategies abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
a childhood behavioural problem characterised by constant disobedience and hostility. oppositional defiant disorder (odd) o oppositional defiant disorder abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

punitive inflicting a punishment for undesired and unproductive behaviour. proximity physical closeness or distance between the teacher and students within a classroom setting. proprioception the bodys ability to sense its position, movement and orientation in space. prompts a verbal reminder of an expected behaviour. proactive praise positively creating or controlling a situation rather than just responding to it after it has happened. post-traumatic stress disorder (ptsd) a mental health condition that can develop after experiencing or witnessing a traumatic event. phases of escalation seven phases of escalation in behaviour occurs when behaviours progressively become more challenging. peak stage 5 of the seven phases of behaviour escalation. the student will not be in control of their emotions or behaviour and will likely exhibit observable risky behaviours. p peak phases of escalation post-traumatic stress disorder proactive praise prompts proprioception proximity punitive abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
q abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

rules one of a set of explicit or understood regulations or principles governing conduct or procedure within a particular area of activity. routines a sequence of actions regularly followed. role-playing strategies to illustrate to students what potential situations actually look like. restorative practices holding students accountable for their actions through repairing harm and making amends, including persons who have harmed or been harmed in the process, and re-engaging students at risk of academic failure and entering the juvenile justice system. replacement behaviour an appropriate behaviour to replace an inappropriate behaviour. recovery stage 7 of the seven phases of behaviour escalation. the students behaviour drops to their usual baseline or even below that and they appear calmer. reactive attachment disorder (rad) a condition where a child doesnt form healthy emotional bonds with their caretakers (parental figures), often because of emotional neglect or abuse at an early age. r reactive attachment disorder recovery replacement behaviour restorative practices role-playing routines rules abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

student diversity students from different social, cultural, community and family backgrounds and students with a wide range of physical, cognitive, sensory and social-emotional abilities. social stories predictable in format and use photographs or drawings that directly relate to the social environment of the student and class, reinforcing the appropriate social skills or responses being taught. self-regulate the ability to understand and manage your own behaviour and reactions. social-emotional learning (sel) social-emotional learning (sel) is the process through which children and young people develop the knowledge, skills and attitudes to develop healthy identities and establish and maintain supportive relationships. scaffold breaking learning into small chunks so students can more easily tackle complex material. it builds on previous knowledge and connects to new knowledge. s scaffold social-emotional learning self-regulate social stories student diversity abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

trigger stage 2 of the seven phases of behaviour escalation. the student experiences conflicts or situations that trigger their behaviour to escalate. trauma a response to distressing events, affecting emotional wellbeing, academic performance and social interactions. tier 3 intensive individualised interventions: systems for students with high-risk behaviour and/or learning needs. tier 2 targeted interventions: small-group systems for students at-risk behaviourally and academically. tier 1 universal prevention: school-wide and classroom systems for all students, staff and settings. take-a-break card a tool to help when a student becomes overwhelmed with a situation. t take-a-break card tier 1 tier 2 tier 3 trauma trigger abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
u abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

vestibular system controls balance, spatial orientation and coordinated movement. verbal strategies directions or instructions given verbally to manage the behaviours of others. v verbal strategies vestibular system abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

wellbeing a student's overall mental state, personal development and quality of life. wait time pausing for 35 seconds to allow students an opportunity to respond to a question or request. w wait time wellbeing abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
x abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
y abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
z abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
